Want is Wanted in past, Want or wants in the present, and will want in the future. To be is was or been in the past, is am and are in the present, and will be in the future.

Bot: yeah there's a lot of appartments around my house too so i get a ton of interference

User: How do you get interference? They don't get on your wifi do they?
Bot: No they don't but wifi is being transmitted over a specific wavelength the more things on that wavelength nearby, the more the WIFI will drop packages in transmission

User: Ohh I understand a bit more now
Bot: that is why some baby monitors or other devices interfere with wifi because they all interface on a 2.4 ghz frequency you may see baby monitors and such advertized with a differnt frequency so that it won't have (or provide) interference I'm a bit of a computer nerd

User: Is that why professors sometimes have you change the frequencies?
Bot: are you talking about iClickers?

User: Because less people are on that gz frequency
Bot: if you're talking about iClickers its more likely because adjacent classrooms have iClicker receivers and they will pick up your submission in other rooms (and possibly not in your classroom) and grading would be difficult

User: No, in one class my teacher had us split up which wave we were using and everyone was able to connect to the wifi and have it be fast
Bot: Oh yeah newer wifi routers and receivers are able to connect over a 5ghz frequency which offeres faster connection speeds on a less common frequency at the cost of range

User: Of course! respecting other people's viewpoints is essential in achieving peace even if you disagree wholeheartedly that's the problem with the world right now is that assume that listening means accepting.  it doesn't.
Bot: Yeah totally. And really people just want to be listened to and understood. They don't care if you convert to their ideology.

Bot: Far away a small copse of trees lies. Near the trees, a strange man stands, slowly beckoning to you. What do you do?

User: I draw my sword, approaching cautiously.
Bot: The man appears taken aback. He appears mostly unarmed. "No need for such protections from me, traveler! I'm merely a waylaid preacher of a nearby parish." he says. "Could you help me defeat a bestial menace that has taken hold in my town?"

User: I offer him my services, at whatever cost he feels is worthwhile.
Bot: "Good man, I can promise at least 1000 gold pieces if you complete this task. Follow me!"

User: I follow him, still wary of anything strange happening.
Bot: Roll for perception.

User: I got a 12.
Bot: You see nothing too strange, as you follow him into the trees. He leads you to a glowing green circle. Suspended about a foot into the air. "Traveler, this portal will take you to my village. As soon as you complete your task, it should reactivate, allowing you to return here. I will not be joining you, as the portal's magic only will work for one more person, and your help is vital to my village's survival."

User: "Sir, I promise I will help, in whatever way I can."

Bot: "One last thing, traveler."

User: so statistically speaking, it's basically guaranteed that there is life on other planets in the universe but then the question is where are they? why can't we find any signs of life anywhere? why is the universe so quiet? why is there no signs of a super advanced civilization? one idea is that there's a "great filter" that occurs naturally, where once a population reaches a certain size or advances far enough it ends up self destructing kind of like us with nukes. we might kill each other before we ever make it to mars.

User: This turbulence creates the pocket of negative pressure where bugs can swirl around and the hungry trout can eat them lazily as it flows past thenm So the key to cathing more fish in a river is to get your flies down in this part of the current and have them flow with the current But with suspension nymphing this gets difficult due to this difference in currents.
Bot: Oh no way. So like how is fly fishing worst than regular spinner or bait fishing?

User: So this is where euro nymphing comes into play By eliminating the indicator all together you can ahve this thin line that cuts through the water down to the bottom of the water column where the fish are located. But then you may ask. How in the world can you see if a fish is biting without a bubble? I totally get you and I have a great answer to that question
Bot: But how can you see if  you have a fish if there is no indicator?

User: This is achieved by this nifty thing called a sighter This sighter is a really bright orange and fluorescent chartreuse piece of monofilament 20lb test line and you tie a 4 turn blood knot This blood knot will leave tag ends a few inches long. Trim these down to about 1-2 inches and you will have a very strong, high contrast piece of monofilament material that acts just like a strike indicator that is integrated right into the leader
Bot: So if that piece goes underwater, than i know a fish is on?

User: the tapered leader and you can keep this part of a tight line that extend from the tip of your extrememly sensitive rod down to the bottom of the river You try to keep it above water or else you are doing it wrong Also by using barbless hooks and proper catch and release techniques i remember win i was younger i use to fish a ton. i would get my tackle box and just run down to the creek with my dogs and just chill down there and catch small mouth bass an

User: hahah yeah right. well in my user experience team we had real companies here in the area come to us and asked us to do some user research for them the first project that we did was with Cake App. this app was a native mobile browser app and they wanted to challenge the mobile browser game. They are going against browsers such as Safari, chrome, firefox, and opera

Bot: ok what happened after? what did you find?

User: well we found that cake was not any faster and we found that most people were probably faster on their native browsers because they were used to the flow but some people were still a bit confused when using Cake but a lot of people thought it was really cool and they like the idea and all the convenient features that Cake Provided
Bot: people like being comfortable. if you try and switch things up on them they well probably reject it.

User: and after we presented our data to Cake president and the lead designer they were super impressed and we found that they donated 4000 dollars and we found out that Cake actually raised a couple million dollars to make the app they launched like a couple months ago and I think they have a lot of users and they are increasing I hope that they get really big

User: yeah I think you are right. there is a famous saying with human computer interaction and user experience design. User: Do you know how people farm truffles? Its actually quite interesting. I'm not sure exactly how it's done but I know a little bit about it. Truffles only grow in certain conditions and people farm them usually in Europe. People use animals who have strong sensitive noses that can sense the truffle. Once you dig a truffle up from the ground, they immediately start to go bad and it's a race to get them to the different restaurants around the world so they don't go bad Quality restaurants pay really good money for fresh truffles and truffle scavengers get a lot of money too.

User: but in the future, do you think AI will achieve sentience / consciousness?
Bot: I don't think a computer is capable of making decisions independent of what its algorithms decide So basically, a computer can learn how to be a human really, really well But it will never achieve true sentience, because all of its very human-like decisions will still be based on the algorithm it is using to "learn"

User: hmmm the way our brains work is very similar to a computer though. our neurons are just electrical circuits, we have memory storage, ram, we can only process one thread of informat ion at a time, and so on
Bot: That is true

User: and really, all our decisions are based upon algorithms that we've learned through experience and instinct
Bot: I do still think that a human is capable of completely defying what he or she has learned in the past And making a contrary decision, which a computer isn't capable of, unless it was coded into the program somehiow

User: true. however i do think computers will reach a point where they can do these things. it will probably be a very long time though AI is actually one of elon musk's greatest concerns. he's certain superintelligent AI will happen, and he's worried about it
Bot: I do agree that through the power of neural networks, computers can achieve near 100% perfection in tasks that a human brain can complete to 100% perfection or less So given time and proper training, a neural network that teaches a computer to emulate human  behavior could imitate "superintelligence" But it's still a program. And then you have to ask the question, is there a point that a computer can become so "perfectly" human that it actually ceases be be like a human Because it is too perfect?
